title: 104_s160
content: The "Immigration Moratorium Act of 1994" defines an immigration moratorium as a 5-year period from October 1, 1994, to September 30, 1999. During the immigration moratorium, the worldwide level of family-sponsored immigrants is set at 325,000 for a fiscal year, with deductions for refugees, spouses and children of U.S. citizens, and certain employment-based immigrants. The worldwide level of family-sponsored immigrants is set at 325,000 for a fiscal year, with deductions for refugees, spouses, and children of U.S. citizens. The worldwide level of employment-based immigrants is 50,000, and the worldwide level of diversity immigrants is zero for a fiscal year. SEC. 4. ALLOTMENT OF VISAS. During the immigration moratorium, visas may be allotted under section 203 of the Immigration and Nationality Act only for spouses and unmarried children of permanent resident aliens and parents of U.S. citizens. In the fiscal year, visas will be allocated to parents of U.S. citizens based on a percentage of the worldwide level of family-sponsored immigrants. Qualified immigrants who are sons and daughters of U.S. citizens or permanent resident aliens will also receive allocated visas based on priority dates. The Act allocates visas to various categories of immigrants, including siblings of U.S. citizens, employment-based immigrants, and diversity immigrants. The number of visas allotted to each category is specified, with some categories receiving zero visas. The Act allocates visas to different immigrant categories, with some categories receiving zero visas. Nothing in the Act limits the visas available to spouses and children of U.S. citizens under a specific section of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Act allocates visas to different immigrant categories, with some categories receiving zero visas. Nothing in the Act limits the visas available to spouses and children of U.S. citizens under a specific section of the Immigration and Nationality Act. SEC. 5. GRANTING IMMIGRANT STATUS. During the immigration moratorium, the Attorney General may only accept petitions for classification under specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act, including spouses or children of U.S. citizens and permanent resident aliens, parents of U.S. citizens, and qualified immigrants with priority dates. During the immigration moratorium, petitions for classification under specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act, including spouses or children of U.S. citizens and permanent resident aliens, parents of U.S. citizens, and qualified immigrants with priority dates, may be accepted. Petitions not meeting these criteria will be returned to the filers. During the immigration moratorium, the annual admission of refugees is limited to 50,000. Immediate relatives are defined as children and spouses of U.S. citizens who acquire citizenship. This Act will take effect upon enactment.
